header: Summer is here, and with the nice sunny time, blog entries are getting a little more scarce. But we still have a few nice morsels for you this week. The Perl6 weekly is back in force, Reini found out an itsy bitsy little thing that, once tweaked, improved the speed of the Perl 5 core testing by a lot, and, uh, I might have full mad scientist while  nobody was looking. So, pour yourself a nice exotic drink, bring the tablet/phone/laptop outside, and enjoy both your PerlWeekly and some of the Sun's warmth! ~ `/anick
subject: Just Another Quiet Summer Week

entries.title: Swiss Perl Workshop: The Early Bird Rides the Camel
entries.text: The Swiss Perl Workshop is coming fast, and it looks like it's going to be jolly good fun.
Want to submit a talk to YAPC::EU? Don't delay because the deadline is June 30th, which is tomorrow, if you like to read your PerlWeekly still hot from the press.
entries.title: Deadline to submit a talk approaching. Don't miss it!

entries.text: Neil shares the numbers for the CPAN pull request challenge  in May. The numbers are going down, but not as quickly as one would have thought -- there are still over 50 CPAN elves making contributions for that month, which ain't bad, ain't bad at all.
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.title: CPAN pull requests in May 2015
YAPC and Perl Workshop participant numbers
entries.text: If you ever wondered how many people attend the different workshops and YAPCs, Gabor has compiled a partial list of those events, from 2013 onwards.
entries.author: gabor_szabo

entries.title: YAPC::NA::2015 Closes Sold-Out Conference
entries.text: The concluding words of the TPF Conferences Staff for YAPC::NA 2015. Sold out with an attendence of over 350 peoples, it's safe to say 2015 was a good YAPC::NA vintage.
No, Dave is not talking about a fight pitting authors versus release tests (although that'd be quite entertaining), but rather the distinction between author tests and release tests.
entries.author: dave_rolsky
entries.title: Author Versus Release Tests with (and without) Dist::Zilla

entries.author: reini_urban
entries.text: Sometimes, performance is performance. Sometimes, it can be improved with lots of hard work. Sometimes, you look in a dark nook of the mystery box and notice a button with "turbo" written on it. Reini was wondering why the Perl code testsuites were so pokie on his mac, and his investigations lead to one such button...
entries.title: How I made my core testsuite 2x faster

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Born out of the desire to compare Dancer 1 and Dancer 2 performances, Yanick proposes a loose framework for web application benchmarks.
entries.title: Web Framework Benchmarking Framework
Include image data in your Perl script or module
entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: Embedding text in a Perl script is no biggie. But how about binary stuff, like images? There's many ways to do it, and Sinan shows a few.

entries.title: Pulp Fiction
entries.text: Inspired by JavaScript's Gulp, Yanick is toy with a Perl-based building system called 'Pulp'.
entries.author: yanick_champoux

entries.title: Catching Up Is Hard To Do
entries.text: The Perl 6 Weekly feel in limbo for 3 weeks, and now liztormato is playing catch up. Exhausting work for them, but this means a plump, juicy collection of links for us.

entries.title: CPAN Great Modules Released Last Week
